In my environmental science class we had gone over "keystone" species, and the fact that without them a eco system would become imbalanced and go into a decline of diversity. Now take humans for example: for a long time we were able to increase diversity and still are, but we as humans have the tendency to make the world suit us over other species and we can, in some cases, destroy diversity entirely. So when i read "destroy all humans" or "no don't destroy all humans because we make the world better" it is neither. We should try and live in harmony with other species and seek that equilibrium, but it is hard to the point of almost being impossible; because human nature dictates we seek to better ourselves either on our own or as a group. The issue being we out compete all forms of life on the planet through intellect and the creation of tools/ machines. In short we sit in the middle of invasive and keystone, both destroying the environment we live in and giving it the ability to grow beyond its normal capacity.

What is wrong with Earth now:

1) The Arctic ice (North and South Pole) are melting by the minute by global warming and climate change... Polar bears, penguins etc will lose their habitat

2) Deforestation means people cutting down a lot of trees. Because of this, the famous Amazon rain forest is being destroyed. People cut down trees for money because they get paid a lot.

3) Pollution is being caused by factories and cars, basically anything industrial. Pollution is also mainly causing global warming. Pollution is letting out carbon dioxide which is bad air. While trees take away the carbon dioxide, trees are being cut down so it releases carbon dioxide.

4) One of the big ones are population. The earth can hold a limit of people before it gets crowded. More food, more water usage and more what I’ve just listed.

Our species has undergone fundamental changes in its history and faced various challenges, and will continue to do so.  Perhaps the greatest challenge awaits us yet.  Older ideologies based on religion, racism, economics, governance, etc. will eventually become obsolete as our species better understands how to manage itself, and the planet...... I used to think that humans need nature but nature doesn't need humans and that it would be the best for this "pale blue dot" if the human race simply went extinct. Something that I hadn't learned then though, and that you didn't mention, is that there are very, very many types of landscapes and thus ecosystems and species that have survived until now, are now directly connected to and depend upon humans' interferance in nature.

(Such as open landscapes that before and during the latest ice age were "naturally" kept open by megaherbivores such as mammoths and other trunked mammals, aurochs, bisons etc. [compare to today's African savannah], and later when most of these went extinct or at least were greatly reduced due to contested reasons [both due to climate change which might have led to habitats becoming overgrown with forest, and human hunting -> more overgrowing & difficulties surviving] were kept half open by smaller herbivores such as giant deers, moose, still/yet bisons, tarpans, beaver etc. These smaller herbivores were also hunted and reduced which led to more forest expansion, and then, about 6000 years ago up here in northern Europe, humans "started agriculture" [first still being nomads/seminomads] and eventually also started keeping livestock [generally settling down] – taking over these wild herbivores' "job" as landscape openers [to some extent, not completely – and of course the landscape was not kept as open as when the megaherbivores roamed the land; it was greatly covered by tress, forest]. A lot of the species – plants, insects, birds, etc. – in some way linked to and dependant on open landscapes & the interferance of grazing animals then retreated to these "sanctuaries" that were kept open by the humans and their livestock, and then continued to co-develop together with them [as well as the still thriving grazing wild animals].)

To repeat one of my two points, there are several types of landscapes [more than most people tend to think], not only up here in northern Europe but all around the world, that depend on human's interferance in nature (e.g. "traditional" hundreds/thousands of years long cultivation/use of the land). Thus (Point #2) if the human species just disappeared from the surface of the earth (orrrr just continued to reproduce and rationalise and scale up the agriculture and silviculture) the consequences for the biodiversity and the planet would be much more complex than this little short video partly understandably didn't describe. A lot – a lot – of other species (and individuals) and complete ecosystems would go extinct with it.

I'm not sure if it's naïve but I guess nature would find a way through it in the end if this did happen, maybe even eventually develop to the better with as much biodiversity and resilience as "before"... but it would take a lot of time to get there.

As humans probably won't disappear anytime soon, the best solution would be if we could develop ways to feed everyone whilst favoring biodiversity without having to become cavemen again... Didn't get there yet though. Any ideas?

This video was way too optimistic about what would happen to Earth. During the last 250-years humans have dumped carbon into the atmosphere that came from the fossil fuels we extracted. It took hundreds-of-millions of years of sunlight falling on planet Earth to fix that carbon and store it. Temperatures are expected to soon rise about 5°C. Evolutionary biologists are seeing evidence that we are now plunging into a 6th mass extinction event. At the rate things are going humans are likely to go extinct by 2050 anyway.

Nuclear power plants (NPP) were designed by nuclear engineers who assumed humans will be around for many decades to operate the safety systems associated with high level radioactive waste storage and eventual deep geological burial. If humans disappear the spent fuel pools will dry out and the fuel rods will begin to burn. They will melt down destroying the containment structures beneath them. The still fueled reactors will also experience core meltdowns, similar to what’s happened at the Fukushima Daiichi NPP. Only this time there will be no one around to try to moderate the collapse and contamination flow. This will happen to hundreds of NPP around the planet. The waste products, emitted by those plants, will create a radiological disaster to this planet that will last for about a half-million years.

All the factors, mentioned above, will likely cause the extinction of tens-of-millions of species that would have lived on if human brilliance hadn’t graced planet Earth.

This is so far off from what would actually happen. It doesn't take so many variables into account.
The part that states that animals will bounce back to the levels we were at before we evolved is based on what? Many species rely on humans, and with us gone, they will affect others in unknown ways. We've reshaped the land and waterways, in ways that many species couldn't possibly go back to the numbers they were at before. Some will go up, some down, while others will go extinct.
This also pretty much ignores climate change reality. If we disappeared today, it doesn't magically fix itself.
In about 50 to 100 years from now half the species today will be extinct. CO² and other greenhouse gases take anywhere from decades to centuries to leave the atmosphere.

Other issues are the many oil rigs and refineries that may further pollute the environment without any maintenance.
Lots of chemical plants will erode and those will also leach out into the waterways and atmosphere.
Running nuclear power plants may have possible meltdowns. The total amount of radioactive waste that exist also wouldn't be maintained and would leach into the environment.

There are so many unknowns that no one could reliably predict what would happen with any degree of certainty if humans suddenly disappeared.
The most likely scenario is that life would continue, and we may be able to make fairly decent guesses as to which, but beyond that is just speculation.

Many people here are debating the selfishness of the human race. Although I agree and constantly see examples of Tragedy of the Commons (a resource will inevitably be over consumed if there are no regulations restricting the consumption) with our race, but when you come down to it, many animals on earth show similar traits that are considered "selfish".
for example, every animal on this earth has a "right' to live. Eating, killing, consuming another organism is having the "right" to survive and reproduce to further its line of species. We see the cutting down of rain forests as an act of murder and bigotry (Mass Clearing for palm oil for products like oreos or candy bars is in my mind, not a justifiable act of cutting down forests), but the farmers and their family are applying this reasoning with their destruction. They have the "right" to eat and live, and if that means killing many organisms and trees with it, then so be it. Even if there is one tiger left in the world, if a family is starving, they will most likely kill and eat it. Same goes with a starving animal. It is how a mind works, any animal is instinctively "selfish". Thus so, I believe the human race is putting immense pressure to the earth and practically creating the sixth mass extinction, it is a process to learn and grow so we don't make these mistakes again and we learn from them. This video fails to consider that the fuel in planet earths 500 plus nuclear power plants would fail to be adequately cooled causing reactor meltdowns (in all cases) in events wherein humans become non-present (or alternatively present but not equipped with necessary resources - i.e. fossil  fuels on site.  E.g. resource supply interruption) to maintain these systems.  The prompt widespread release of these power plants (not just the material in their reactors but also in their cooling pools, etc.) radioactive material would be catastrophic for many/most animal (and plant) species on this planet.  Death would (will) be overwhelmingly abundant within months.  Natural systems will disperse the offending material into all ecosystems within years.  Given the long half-life of much of this fuel's isotopes and its distributed mass one should not expect that complex lifeforms would have opportunity to re-evolve before our solar system's sun has significantly expanded its output rendering such evolution impossible.

If nuclear war destroys humanity and most of the rest of life, a good bet for survival in the short term, and for evolutionary ancestry in the long term, is rats. I have a post-Armageddon vision. We and all other large animals are gone. Rodents emerge as the ultimate post-human scavengers. They gnaw their way through New York, London and Tokyo, digesting spilled larders, ghost supermarkets and human corpses and turning them into new generations of rats and mice, whose racing populations explode out of the cities and into the countryside. When all the relics of human profligacy are eaten, populations crash again, and the rodents turn on each other, and on the cockroaches scavenging with them. In a period of intense competition, short generations perhaps with radioactivity enhanced mutation-rates boost rapid evolution. With human ships and planes gone, islands become islands again, with local populations isolated save for occasional lucky raftings: ideal conditions for evolutionary divergence. Within 5 million years, a whole range of new species replace the ones we know. Herds of giant grazing rats are stalked by sabre-toothed predatory rats.* Given enough time, will a species of intelligent, cultivated rats emerge? Will rodent historians and scientists eventually organise careful archaeological digs (gnaws?) through the strata of our long-compacted cities, and reconstruct the peculiar and temporarily tragic circumstances that gave ratkind its big break?”- Richard Dawkins

Who were the first species to break the confines of being stuck on Earth? Human beings.

We aren't the first organism to change the planet. Early bacteria created a methane atmosphere and life revolved around that until photosynthesis came about and the oxygen waste reacted with methane and removed it from the atmosphere and over time, the oxygen rusted all the dry land and what not, making it looks like Mars on land. Then the removal of the greenhouse gas methane and CO2 would make a snowball earth. Life was very compressed in that era, but after the snowball earth melted, the extra oxygen would push life into alliances, resulted in some bacteria living inside others and eukaryotes would be born. 

Eukaryotes would go on for a long time and eventually started living in colonies, such as things like volvox and a few specialization cells would appear, but eventually, the greater life would yet again overwhelm the Earth and remove enough greenhouse gas to cause another snowball earth. After this one, the higher oxygen levels would result in multicellular life as we move into the Ediacarian period and various filter feeders would come about.

At some point, burrow wormlike organisms would appear and expose the microbial mats to oxygen and caused a massive die off of the ocean floor and setting the stage for the Cambrian explosion. The loss of the microbial mats made CO2 levels soar and the shallow seas forming over parts of the continents would add minerals to the water, so life could use it to evolve shells. Coral would evolve along with shellfish, trilobites, and the first major carnivore, anomalocaris. When the warming spiked, ocean imbalance made the ancient coral reefs go extinct and were replaced by strolomatite mats again, which was a carbon sink to cool the world and eventually coral reefs, more like the family we know would reevolve in the Ordovician and start the warm trend again and in this time frame, the nautiloids, the crinids, and more bryozoans, creating tiering of filter feeds on the ocean floor. Moss would start to colonize land along the waters edge and would eventually drain the atmosphere of carbon and cause an ice age, which would lower sea levels and kill the mosses, which then decompose and release the carbon, warming the earth back up again, causing the first of the mass extinction events. Moss of all things. What a greedy organism.

And it didn't even go extinct, it went on to evolve into vascular plants in the Silurian. In the seas, fish continued to evolve and during this time frame, sea scorpions were huge predators. Life continued to develop on land, with mites, centipedes, millipedes, etc, coming before the insects and fish eventually coming onto land as amphibians later on as we move into the Devonian. Giant mushrooms came before the trees, perhaps as a way to transform the land into a place suitable for trees. The primitive trees related to club moss and ferns came about and broke the soils and rock inland until eventually, the extra nutrients in the ocean caused an algae bloom and a huge marine extinction that would be the second mass extinction.

Moving on to the Carboniferous, trees develop bigger and create undecomposable bark which creates coal swamps. The carbon sink boosted up oxygen levels and insects and amphibians evolved to be huge in high oxygen conditions. Being unsustainable though, eventually there was an ice age and the coal swamps died, closing out the Carboniferous and leading into the Permian, when Pangaea would form and the climate would be dry. Reptiles appeared in the previous period, but would diversify, leading to the sailfin reptiles like dimetrodon and would later become the synopsids, mammal-like reptiles, which would eventually become mammals in the next time period. But first, a volcanic event that lasted a 100 thousand years in Siberia, would release most of the carbon trapped in the coal from the Carboniferous and global warming would happen, complete with ocean currents releasing the methane ice in the water, making the world extra warm and the oceans hostile to life and this would be the third mass extinction event and the worst of them with something like 90% of species going extinct.

The low oxygen conditions of the Triassic, which followed the Permian, would favor the ancestors of the dinosaur, because of the superior lung capabilities that birds still have today while the mammals would have to remain small creatures. Many reptiles dominated the Triassic though and dinosaurs wouldn't fully manifest till the Jurassic. I don't quite understand the Triassic mass extinction, but another volcanic event was happening as Pangaea began to split in the middle. 

The Jurassic brought about bigger dinosaurs like allosaurs, stegosaurs, and the sauropods and later on in the cretaceous, the evolution of flowering plants favored the ceratopsids, the ankylosaurs, the hadrosaurs, and the subsequent T-rex. A volcanic event in India started to happen at the end of the Cretaceous, followed by a meteor resulting in the 5th major extinction. Mammals would evolve as the big animals, now that oxygen levels were higher while the surviving dinosaurs, the birds, would remain small mostly, sometimes a large bird evolved on and off. Humans come about and learn to kill keystone species like mammoths that shape the biomes via their eating habits, starting the 6th extinction event, which would slow until industrialization, which is pushing us to be the next harbringers of doom. Life will adapt and go on though. It will go on.

I get the whole wanting to know how the planet will change after human's disappear, but on a personal level I'm more interested in means of HOW all humans would just disappear or even just die off.

The carbon cycle isn't a switch that is turned off via our existence, The lack of life will result in a fairly immediate drop in CO2 however the increased animal life due to increase heat from the sun = more life = MORE CO2.

More CO2 does NOT = more heat its actually the other way around (scientists have known this fact for a long time, it just doesn't suit the "GIVE ME YOUR MONEY TO SAVE DA EARTHS" agenda) 

Tl:DR Yes we humans produce CO2, but if CO2 was never absorbed by our biosphere/ocean we'd be like Venus a LONG LONG time ago, Our sudden and massive production of CO2 isn't going to change the laws of physics.

After evolving in Africa about 1 million years ago, lions quickly spread to Eurasia and soon reached North America, where they lasted until 9,000 BC. In 2005, a paper was published advocating for Pleistocene rewilding, which would involve restoring species native to North America during prehistoric times or their closest relatives. This would mean introducing horses (already back), llamas, camels, tapirs, elephants, and yes, lions. Lions on the Great Plains would really be the restoration of a native species.
